elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of N-piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid (H2pmp) and oxalate anion with trivalent rare earth metal ions yielded 13 rare earth oxalatophosphonates with three closely related structural types, ranging from two-dimensional (2D) networks to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. They are formulated as [Ln3(Hpmp)3(C2O4)2(H2O)5](ClO4)2·9H2O [Ln = Gd (1), Eu (2), Tb(3), type I structure], [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]·H2O [Ln = Gd (5), Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), Er (11), Yb (12), Y (13), type II structure], and [Gd3(Hpmp)(C2O4)4(H2O)6]·5H2O [(4), type III structure]. Their structures were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy, elemental analysis (EA), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), except that the structures of compounds 2 and 3 were confirmed by PXRD, IR, and EA. The effects of reaction conditions including pH value, reaction temperature, counterion, and stoichiometry of the starting materials on the structures have been discussed. Furthermore, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of the Eu (2 and 7) and Tb (3 and 8) compounds have been measured at room temperature. The two types of Eu and Tb compounds display intense red and green luminescence emissions, respectively, with lifetimes at the millisecond order.

The two types of Eu and Tb compounds display intense red and green luminescence emissions, respectively, with lifetimes at the millisecond order.

elements.content: Three closely related structural types of rare earth metal oxalatophosphonates ranging from two-dimensional (2D) networks to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The influence of several reaction conditions on the structures has been investigated. Photoluminescence properties of the two types of Eu(III) and Tb(III) compounds have also been analyzed.

The influence of several reaction conditions on the structures has been investigated. Photoluminescence properties of the two types of Eu(III) and Tb(III) compounds have also been analyzed.

elements.content: The design, synthesis, and characterization of luminescent lanthanide−organic frameworks are one of the most rapidly developing areas of materials research. The intense interests in this area are driven by not only their aesthetically beautiful structures but also their potential applications, such as biological assays, medical imaging reagents, light-emitting diodes, laser systems, and optical fibers for telecommunications. Trivalent lanthanide ions are fascinating luminescence sources for their high color purity and relatively long lifetimes (millisecond order) arising from electronic transitions within the partially filled 4f-shell of the ions. The shielding of the 4f-orbitals by the filled 5s25p6 subshells makes the 4f-electrons share little disturbance from the surrounding ligands, thus accounting for the characteristic luminescence emissions of the lanthanide ions in spite of the environment around them. More recently, organophosphonate has been exploited to be one of the most attractive ligands for building lanthanide-containing materials because of their versatile coordination modes, as well as the good thermal and chemical stabilities of the Ln−O−P bonds that phosphonate ligands made with lanthanide ions. However, the further exploitation of such materials is still limited, and the bottleneck lies in the low solubility and poor crystallinity of lanthanide phosphonates. Some substantial progress has been made by Clearfield, Lin, Bligh, and Mao et al. by modifying the phosphonate ligands with other functional groups through organic synthetic approaches or introducing auxiliary ligands into the lanthanide phosphonate system. Among these auxiliary ligands, oxalate was found to be an efficient assistant because of its versatile coordination mode, as well as the high and variable coordination number of lanthanide ions. Oxalate anion can chelate Ln ions to form a series of complex lanthanide oxalates, from commonly known Ln(C2O4) n (n = 1−4) moieties to rarely observed Ln(C2O4)5 units. More importantly, due to the π-conjugated character, the divalent oxalate anion is an effective bridge for charge and energy transfer between metal centers that it links, making it a good chromophore as lanthanide luminescence sensitizer. However, reported lanthanide oxalatephosphonates with definite structures are still limited. N-Piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid (H2pmp for short), a readily prepared zwitterionic ligand by the Mannich reaction, shows good solubility in water. It can ligate to metal ions with a series of coordination modes, from tridentate to hexadentate and from bridging to chelating-bridging. The coordination of trivalent rare earth metal ions with Hpmp− and oxalate anions under hydrothermal conditions with different stoichiometries, reaction temperature, and pH values produced a series of rare earth oxalatophosphonates, from samarium(III) to ytterbium(III) and yttrium(III). They are formulated as [Ln3(Hpmp)3(C2O4)2(H2O)5](ClO4)2·9H2O [Ln = Gd (1), Eu (2), Tb (3)], [Gd3(Hpmp)(C2O4)4(H2O)6]·5H2O (4), and [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]·H2O [Ln = Gd (5), Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), Er (11), Yb (12), Y (13)]. They feature three structural types ranging from two-dimensional (2D) networks to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Herein we report their syntheses, structure analyses, and photoluminescence properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design, synthesis, and characterization of luminescent lanthanide-organic frameworks are one of the most rapidly developing areas of materials research. The intense interests in this area are driven by not only their aesthetically beautiful structures but also their potential applications, such as biological assays, medical imaging reagents, light-emitting diodes, laser systems, and optical fibers for telecommunications. Trivalent lanthanide ions are fascinating luminescence sources for their high color purity and relatively long lifetimes (millisecond order) arising from electronic transitions within the partially filled 4f-shell of the ions. The shielding of the 4f-orbitals by the filled 5s25p6 subshells makes the 4f-electrons share little disturbance from the surrounding ligands, thus accounting for the characteristic luminescence emissions of the lanthanide ions in spite of the environment around them. More recently, organophosphonate has been exploited to be one of the most attractive ligands for building lanthanide-containing materials because of their versatile coordination modes, as well as the good thermal and chemical stabilities of the Ln-O-P bonds that phosphonate ligands made with lanthanide ions. However, the further exploitation of such materials is still limited, and the bottleneck lies in the low solubility and poor crystallinity of lanthanide phosphonates. Some substantial progress has been made by Clearfield, Lin, Bligh, and Mao et al. by modifying the phosphonate ligands with other functional groups through organic synthetic approaches or introducing auxiliary ligands into the lanthanide phosphonate system. Among these auxiliary ligands, oxalate was found to be an efficient assistant because of its versatile coordination mode, as well as the high and variable coordination number of lanthanide ions. Oxalate anion can chelate Ln ions to form a series of complex lanthanide oxalates, from commonly known Ln(C2O4) n  (n = 1-4) moieties to rarely observed Ln(C2O4)5 units. More importantly, due to the π-conjugated character, the divalent oxalate anion is an effective bridge for charge and energy transfer between metal centers that it links, making it a good chromophore as lanthanide luminescence sensitizer. However, reported lanthanide oxalatephosphonates with definite structures are still limited. N-Piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid (H2pmp for short), a readily prepared zwitterionic ligand by the Mannich reaction, shows good solubility in water. It can ligate to metal ions with a series of coordination modes, from tridentate to hexadentate and from bridging to chelating-bridging. The coordination of trivalent rare earth metal ions with Hpmp- and oxalate anions under hydrothermal conditions with different stoichiometries, reaction temperature, and pH values produced a series of rare earth oxalatophosphonates, from samarium(III) to ytterbium(III) and yttrium(III). They are formulated as [Ln3(Hpmp)3(C2O4)2(H2O)5](ClO4)2⋅9H2O [Ln = Gd (1), Eu (2), Tb (3)], [Gd3(Hpmp)(C2O4)4(H2O)6]⋅5H2O (4), and [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]⋅H2O [Ln = Gd (5), Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), Er (11), Yb (12), Y (13)]. They feature three structural types ranging from two-dimensional (2D) networks to three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Herein we report their syntheses, structure analyses, and photoluminescence properties.

elements.content: N-Piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid hydrochloride (H2pmp·HCl) was synthesized by our previous method. Ln(ClO4)3 was prepared by dissolving the corresponding Ln2O3 in 70% perchloric acid (Caution! Perchlorate salts are potentially dangerous as explosives and should only be handled in small quantities carefully). All the other starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Vario MICRO EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One instrument as KBr pellets in the range of 4000−400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out with a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of compounds 1−13 were collected on a Rigaku Mini Flex2 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) under ambient conditions. Solid-state luminescent spectra of compounds 2, 3, 7, and 8 were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The instrument is equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

N-Piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid hydrochloride (H2pmp⋅HCl) was synthesized by our previous method. Ln(ClO4)3 was prepared by dissolving the corresponding Ln2O3 in 70% perchloric acid (Caution! Perchlorate salts are potentially dangerous as explosives and should only be handled in small quantities carefully). All the other starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Vario MICRO EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One instrument as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out with a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of compounds 1-13 were collected on a Rigaku Mini Flex2 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) under ambient conditions. Solid-state luminescent spectra of compounds 2, 3, 7, and 8 were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The instrument is equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source.

A mixture of Gd(ClO4)3 (1 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) and H2pmp·HCl (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in deionized water (4 mL) was stirred and heated to about 90 °C on a heating plate. The pH value was adjusted to 5.1 by adding 0.5 M aqueous NaOH dropwise. Then 2 mL of aqueous Na2C2O4 (0.010 g, 0.075 mmol) was added. The clear solution thus formed was maintained undisturbed at 100 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C/h. Colorless rod-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried. Yield: 88% (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C22H67Cl2Gd3N3O39P3 (1633.35): C, 16.18; H, 4.13; N, 2.57%. Found: C, 16.23; H, 4.03; N, 2.48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3408(vs, br), 2950(m), 2788(w), 1648(vs), 1457(w), 1317(m), 1114(vs), 1010(s), 797(w), 627(m), 564(w), 500(w).

elements.content: A mixture of GdCl3·6H2O (0.156 g, 0.42 mmol), H2pmp·HCl (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), Na2C2O4(0.054 g, 0.4 mmol), and deionized water (8 mL) was stirred, while 0.5 M aqueous NaOH was added drop by drop until the pH value reached 3.8. After 0.5 h of stirring, it was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, and heated at 135 °C for 96 h, then slowly cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless block-shaped crystals of compounds 4 and 5 were recovered by filtration, washed repeatedly with deionized water, and air-dried. Overall yield: 49% (based on Na2C2O4, calculated as the average yield of compounds 4 and 5). Synthesis of [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]⋅H2O [Ln = Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8)]

The synthetic process was similar to that for compounds 4 and 5 but using the corresponding LnCl3⋅6H2O (0.42 mmol), H2pmp⋅HCl (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), and Na2C2O4 (0.054 g, 0.4 mmol) as the reactants. Light yellow crystals were collected. Yield: 22% for 6 (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C11H21NO17PSm2 (770.96): C, 17.14; H, 2.75; N, 1.82%. Found: C, 16.65; H, 3.00; N, 1.68%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3407(s, br), 2977(w), 2792(w), 1634(vs), 1472(w), 1316(m), 1108(s), 1016(m), 800(m), 551(w), 481(w). Colorless crystals were obtained. Yield: 37% for 7 (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C11H21Eu2NO17P (774.18): C, 17.07; H, 2.73; N, 1.81%. Found: C, 16.73; H, 2.97; N, 1.66%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3400(s, br), 2974(w), 2788(w), 1634(vs), 1470(w), 1318(s), 1107(s), 1014(m), 794(m), 550(w), 492(w). Colorless crystals were collected. Yield: 63% for 8 (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C11H21NO17PTb2 (788.10): C, 16.76; H, 2.69; N, 1.78%. Found: C, 16.26; H, 2.76; N, 1.57%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3409(vs, br), 2976(w), 2790(w), 1636(vs), 1470(w), 1319(s), 1106(s), 1016(m), 795(m), 552(w), 488(w).

elements.content: Crystal structure determinations were performed on Rigaku Saturn-724 (for compounds 1 and 12), Rigaku Saturn-70 (for compound 11), Rigaku Mercury (for compounds 4, 9, and 13), and Rigaku SCXmini (for compounds 5−8 and 10) CCD-based diffractometers equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The intensity data sets were collected with the ω-scan technique. The CrytalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL Version 5.1). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to C and N atoms were generated geometrically and refined by a riding-mode with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.2 times that of the mother atoms. Hydrogen atoms bonding to water molecules were located from Fourier difference maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.5 times that of the O atoms. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries of compounds 1 and 4−13 are detailed in Table . Selected bond lengths for compounds 1, 4, and 5 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths for compounds 6−13 are listed in Table S1 in the .

X-ray Crystallographic Study

Crystal structure determinations were performed on Rigaku Saturn-724 (for compounds 1 and 12), Rigaku Saturn-70 (for compound 11), Rigaku Mercury (for compounds 4, 9, and 13), and Rigaku SCXmini (for compounds 5-8 and 10) CCD-based diffractometers equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The intensity data sets were collected with the ω-scan technique. The CrytalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structures were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXTL Version 5.1). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms attached to C and N atoms were generated geometrically and refined by a riding-mode with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.2 times that of the mother atoms. Hydrogen atoms bonding to water molecules were located from Fourier difference maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.5 times that of the O atoms. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries of compounds 1 and 4-13 are detailed in Table . Selected bond lengths for compounds 1, 4, and 5 are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths for compounds 6-13 are listed in Table S1 in the .

elements.content: As illustrated in Scheme , three structural types of rare earth oxalatophosphonates have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. They are [Ln3(Hpmp)3(C2O4)2(H2O)5](ClO4)2·9H2O [Ln = Gd (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), type I structure], [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]·H2O [Ln = Gd (5), Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), Er (11), Yb (12), Y (13), type II structure], and [Gd3(Hpmp)(C2O4)4(H2O)6]·5H2O [(4), type III structure]. Compounds 1−3 representing the type I structure are 2D layered networks. Compounds 5−13 and 4 belonging to the type II and III structures, respectively, are 3D frameworks. Good quality crystals of 1 were obtained in high yield by the reaction of Gd(ClO4)3 with H2pmp and oxalate anions at a temperature of ca. 100 °C and a pH of 5.1. Type I crystals in the other Ln(ClO4)3-H2pmp-C2O4 2− reaction systems cannot be prepared under the same reaction condition. However, the powder samples of Eu(2) and Tb(3) analogues can be obtained by a similar method (as described in the ), and their purities have been confirmed by PXRD, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and elemental analysis (EA) (Figure S1−S4 in ). When the reaction temperature was raised to 135 °C and the pH value was declined to 3.8, type II structures are the final products. The different results under different reaction temperatures may be caused by a different reaction mechanism: the reaction mechanism shifts from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain when the reaction temperature is raised from 100 to 135 °C. This is also consistent with the fact that the 3D framework is comparatively more stable than the 2D network and enhanced reaction temperature favors the formation of high dimensional products, just as indicated by the results of the thermogravimetric analyses. It should be mentioned that a reaction temperature higher than 140 °C resulted in severe decomposition of the Hpmp− ligand and thus lowered crystal yield. To assess the effect of counterions on the structural evolution, Ln(ClO4)3, Ln(NO3)3, and LnCl3 were used as the metal sources, respectively. The results showed that (a) type II products were obtained in all cases under 135 °C reaction temperature, but the yield and purity for the Ln(ClO4)3 and Ln(NO3)3 systems were significantly lowered; (b) type I structure was only isolated when Ln(ClO4)3 (Ln = Eu, Gd, Tb) was used as the starting material, indicating the necessity of the presence of the “large size” ClO4 − counterion in the crystallization process.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As illustrated in Scheme , three structural types of rare earth oxalatophosphonates have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions. They are [Ln3(Hpmp)3(C2O4)2(H2O)5](ClO4)2⋅9H2O [Ln = Gd (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), type I structure], [Ln2(Hpmp)(C2O4)2.5(H2O)3]⋅H2O [Ln = Gd (5), Sm (6), Eu (7), Tb (8), Dy (9), Ho (10), Er (11), Yb (12), Y (13), type II structure], and [Gd3(Hpmp)(C2O4)4(H2O)6]⋅5H2O [(4), type III structure]. Compounds 1-3 representing the type I structure are 2D layered networks. Compounds 5-13 and 4 belonging to the type II and III structures, respectively, are 3D frameworks. Good quality crystals of 1 were obtained in high yield by the reaction of Gd(ClO4)3 with H2pmp and oxalate anions at a temperature of ca. 100 °C and a pH of 5.1. Type I crystals in the other Ln(ClO4)3-H2pmp-C2O4 2- reaction systems cannot be prepared under the same reaction condition. However, the powder samples of Eu(2) and Tb(3) analogues can be obtained by a similar method (as described in the ), and their purities have been confirmed by PXRD, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and elemental analysis (EA) (Figure S1-S4 in ). When the reaction temperature was raised to 135 °C and the pH value was declined to 3.8, type II structures are the final products. The different results under different reaction temperatures may be caused by a different reaction mechanism: the reaction mechanism shifts from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain when the reaction temperature is raised from 100 to 135 °C. This is also consistent with the fact that the 3D framework is comparatively more stable than the 2D network and enhanced reaction temperature favors the formation of high dimensional products, just as indicated by the results of the thermogravimetric analyses. It should be mentioned that a reaction temperature higher than 140 °C resulted in severe decomposition of the Hpmp- ligand and thus lowered crystal yield. To assess the effect of counterions on the structural evolution, Ln(ClO4)3, Ln(NO3)3, and LnCl3 were used as the metal sources, respectively. The results showed that (a) type II products were obtained in all cases under 135 °C reaction temperature, but the yield and purity for the Ln(ClO4)3 and Ln(NO3)3 systems were significantly lowered; (b) type I structure was only isolated when Ln(ClO4)3 (Ln = Eu, Gd, Tb) was used as the starting material, indicating the necessity of the presence of the "large size" ClO4 - counterion in the crystallization process.

elements.content: Obviously, there is a strong competition between Hpmp− and C2O4 2− when coordinated with Ln(III) ions in the reaction system. As compared to Hpmp−, the oxalate anion shows a stronger binding character to lanthanide center due to its chelating nature. Besides, the first and second dissociation constants of oxalic acid are 5.9 × 10−2 (Ka1) and 6.4 × 10−5 (Ka2), respectively, larger than those for H3PO4 (Ka1 = 7.6 × 10−3, Ka2 = 6.3 × 10−8). In other words, the deprotonation pH values of the phosphonate group are higher than those for H2C2O4. Following this concept, higher pH value and lower C2O4 2− concentration in the reaction system can enhance the coordination competence of phosphonate group and thus the proportion of Hpmp− ligands in the crystal structure. Therefore, higher pH value and lower C2O4 2− concentration are other two preferences for the formation of type I structure than for type II structure, consistent with the experimental results.

Besides, the first and second dissociation constants of oxalic acid are 5.9 × 10-2 (Ka1) and 6.4 × 10-5 (Ka2), respectively, larger than those for H3PO4 (Ka1 = 7.6 × 10-3, Ka2 = 6.3 × 10-8). In other words, the deprotonation pH values of the phosphonate group are higher than those for H2C2O4. Following this concept, higher pH value and lower C2O4 2- concentration in the reaction system can enhance the coordination competence of phosphonate group and thus the proportion of Hpmp- ligands in the crystal structure. elements.content: Interestingly, compound 4 was obtained as a symbiotic product of compound 5 in the reaction of GdCl3 with H2pmp and oxalate anions at 135 °C. Their appearances are slightly different, making it difficult to separate them visually. Similar phenomenon was also observed in some other lanthanide complexes, for which the variable coordination mode and high coordination number of the lanthanide ions may be responsible. Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the structure of compound 4 is closely related to that of 5, except for some differences on the component stoichiometry. The proportion of lattice water molecules (compared to Gd ions) in type III structure is higher than that in type II structure, namely, the type II structure is relatively compact compared to the type III structure. In addition, the type III product was only obtained from the GdCl3-H2pmp-C2O4 2− reaction system, and the attempt to isolate other type III derivatives was unsuccessful, as confirmed by the XRD patterns of the type II structures (). The reason why this occurs is still under investigation, but to some extent, the specialty of Gd(III) which lies in the middle of the lanthanide series may provide the answer. It also suggests the kinetic nature of type III structure.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the structure of compound 4 is closely related to that of 5, except for some differences on the component stoichiometry. It also suggests the kinetic nature of type III structure.

elements.content: It should be mentioned that, to the best of our knowledge, compounds 1−3 are the first example of 2D lanthanide oxalatophosphonates. Such a “low” temperature hydrothermal reaction may be an applicable method for preparing low dimensional lanthanide oxalatophosphonates. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that compounds 5−13 are isostructural, and the unit cell volumes and the Ln−O bond lengths decrease on going from Sm (6) to Yb (12), as expected for the lanthanide contraction. Compounds 1, 5, and 4 are selected as representatives to elucidate the three structural types.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of compound 1 reveals that it crystallizes in the P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit consists of the following structural elements: three crystallographically independent Gd(III) ions, three Hpmp− ligands, one C2O4 2− anion, two half-occupied C2O4 2− moieties, five aqua ligands, two ClO4 − counterions, and several lattice water molecules. All atoms lie in general positions. As shown in Figure , all the Gd(III) ions are eight-coordinated by oxygen atoms from Hpmp−, C2O4 2− and aqua ligands, forming distorted square antiprism [GdO8] coordination geometries. The Gd−O bond lengths range from 2.283(7) to 2.562(7) Å with an average value of about 2.409 Å (Table ), similar to those of other eight-coordinated Gd(III) ions in oxalatophosphonates. Hpmp− ligands bridge three Gd(III) ions like a tripod. They adopted two slightly different coordination modes which are commonly encountered for phosphonate groups: (a) three-coordinate to three Gd ions in a bridging mode, 3.111; (b) four-coordinate to three Gd ions in a chelating-bridging mode, 3.211 (Scheme ). The interconnection of Gd(III) ions by six Hpmp− ligands results in a centrosymmetric hexanuclear [Gd6(Hpmp)6] cluster (Figure ). The inversion center lies in the center of the parallelogram formed by Gd(1), Gd(2), Gd(1) [1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z] and Gd(2) [1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z]. The two border lengths of the parallelogram are 4.000 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(2)) and 5.718 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(2) [1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z]), respectively. The torsion angle ∠Gd(1)−Gd(2)−Gd(1) [1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z] is 67.43°. Gd(3) and Gd(3) [1 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z] are located slightly (0.251 Å) above and below the parallelogrammic plane, respectively. C2O4 2− anions adopted the most commonly observed bis-bidentate coordination mode, chelating to two Gd(III) ions forming two edge-sharing five-membered rings (Gd−O−C−C−O). The dihedral angle in C(19)C(20)O4 is 175.8°, while the other two oxalate ligands [C(21)2O4 and C(22)2O4] are centrosymmetric. As depicted in Figure , each [Gd6(Hpmp)6] unit is linked to six neighboring equivalents by eight C2O4 2− ligands, forming a microporous layer in the crystallographic ac plane. The pores consist of two kinds of rings: 20-membered pseudopentagonal ring composed of five Gd(III) ions, two Hpmp− and three C2O4 2− ligands (ring A); 16-membered pseudotetragonal ring comprised of four Gd(III) ions, two Hpmp− and two C2O4 2− ligands (ring B). C5H10NHCH2 moieties of the Hpmp− ligands take up the interlayer space and point to the b-axis direction. The charge-positive layers are charge balanced by dissociative perchloate anions filling up the remaining interlayer space along with lattice water molecules.

elements.content: As depicted in Figure , there are two crystallographically unique Gd(III) ions, one Hpmp− ligand, two C2O4 2− units, one-half-occupied C2O4 2− moiety, three aqua ligands, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit of 5. Similar to compound 1, it crystallizes in the P1̅ space group, and all atoms lie in general positions. Both Gd(1) and Gd(2) are eight-coordinated by oxygen atoms from phosphonate groups, C2O4 2− and aqua ligands, and the resulting coordination polyhedra of Gd(III) ions adopted distorted square antiprism geometry. The Gd−O bond lengths range from 2.254(6) to 2.504(7) Å with an average value of ca. 2.404 Å (see Table ), comparable to those in 1. Hpmp− ligand adopted the 3.111 coordination mode (mode a, Scheme ). As illustrated in Figure , the linkage of Gd(III) ions by a pair of centrosymmetric Hpmp− ligands led to a parallelogram-shape tetranuclear unit [Gd4(Hpmp)2] with an inversion center that lies in the middle. The two border lengths of the parallelogram are 5.798 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(2)) and 5.979 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(2) [2 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z]), respectively, and the torsion angle ∠Gd(1)−Gd(2)−Gd(1) [2 − x, 1 − y, 1 − z] is 58.60°. The border lengths are longer than those observed in 1, in that the Hpmp− ligands linking the Gd ions adopted a different coordination mode. Oxalate ligands adopted the same coordination pattern as that in 1. The dihedral angles in C(7)C(8)O4 and C(9)C(10)O4 are 176.9° and 175.1°, respectively, while C(11)2O4 lies in an inversion center. Interestingly, the interconnection of two equivalents of Gd ions by two and a half equivalents of chelating-bridging C2O4 2− anions results in the formation of a 1D porous chain {Gd2(C2O4)2.5} n n+ (Figure ) extending along the b-axis, wherein the cavities are formed by 24-membered pseudohexagonal rings. The ring consisting of six Gd ions and six oxalate anions fused with two adjacent equivalents in an edge-sharing mode. It must be noted that this is completely different from the 3D structure of the {Ln2(C2O4)2.5} n n+ units observed in some other lanthanide oxalatophosphonates. The above two kinds of building blocks are interlinked into a 3D porous framework, in which the voids are occupied by the C5H10NHCH2 moieties of the Hpmp− ligands (Figure ). So the structure of 5 can be seen as the Hpmp− ligands hung in the pores generated by {Gd2(C2O4)2.5} n n+.

elements.content: zCompound 4 crystallizes in P21/c space group. As shown in Figure , there are three crystallographically distinct Gd(III) ions, one Hpmp− ligand, three C2O4 2− units, two half-occupied C2O4 2− moieties, six aqua ligands, and five lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit of 4. Three Gd(III) ions exhibit two different coordination numbers. Gd(1) is eight-coordinated with an O8 donor set, and the coordination polyhedron can be described as a slightly distorted square antiprism. Six of the oxygen atoms are from three chelating oxalate anions, one from phosphonate group and one from aqua ligand. Gd(3) is also 8-fold coordinated by oxygen atoms, two from a pair of phosphonate groups, two from a chelating oxalate anion, and the other four are aqua ligands. Gd(2) is nine-coordinated by oxygen atoms with a distorted monocapped square antiprism coordination geometry. Eight of the oxygen atoms come from four chelating oxalate ligands and the remaining ligand sphere is saturated by a water molecule. The Gd−O bond lengths range from 2.244(3)Å to 2.531(3) Å (Table ), with an average value of ca. 2.401 Å for eight-coordinated Gd(III) ions and 2.452 Å for nine-coordinated Gd(III) ion, all of which are within the range of those observed for other Gd(III) complexes with oxygen donor ligands. Hpmp− ligand adopted the same coordination mode as that in 5. As exhibited in Figure , two Gd(3) ions are linked by a pair of Hpmp− ligands to form a dimeric unit, and such dimeric units are further bridged to each other via oxalate anions (C(14)2O4) along the a-axis, forming a “zigzag” chain {Gd2(Hpmp)2(C2O4) } m 2m+. On the other hand, the interconnection of Gd(1) and Gd(2) by three and a half equivalents of oxalate anions (C(7)C(8)O4, C(9)C(10)O4, C(11)C(12)O4, and C(13)2O4) results in a 3D porous framework {Gd2(C2O4)3.5} n n− with tunnels running along the a-axis (Figure ). The tunnels are formed by 40-membered rings consisting of 10 Gd ions and 10 oxalate ligands. The above two types of building blocks are cross-linked to each other via coordination of Gd(1) with the remaining oxygen atom of phosphonate group. Therefore, the structure of 4 can be visually described as “zigzag” chains {Gd2(Hpmp)2(C2O4) } m 2m+ interpenetrated in the tunnels produced by {Gd2(C2O4)3.5} n n− as displayed in Figure . Lattice water molecules filled up the remaining space in the tunnel. Extensive hydrogen bonds exist between donors (NH+ groups, lattice water molecules and aqua ligands) and receptors (lattice water molecules and framework oxygen atoms), as indicated by many O(H)···O and N(H)···O distances ranging from 2.580 to 3.039 Å. Another interesting structure feature in 4 is that the interconnection of Gd(1) and Gd(3) by a pair of centrosymmetric Hpmp− anions leads to a parallelogram-shaped tetranuclear unit [Gd4(Hpmp)2] similar to that of 3 (Figure ). The two border lengths are 5.670 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(3)) and 6.032 Å (Gd(1)−Gd(3) [2 − x, 2 − y, 1 − z]), respectively, and the torsion angle ∠Gd(1)−Gd(3)−Gd(1) [2 − x, 2 − y, 1 − z] is 51.02°, comparable to those in 5.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−13 were examined by thermaogravemetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C (see Figure S14−S15 in ). The TGA curve of 1 displayed two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 40 to 135 °C was observed to be about 9.1%, corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.9%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposed slowly. The second step of weight loss covered a temperature range of 327−427 °C, during which the curves showed a sharp drop, indicative of the partial combustion of the ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious exothermic peak in this temperature range, which may be illustrated as ClO4−-assisted combustion of the ligands. Then the compound continued to decompose slowly above this temperature and complete decomposition was not achieved until above 1000 °C, which was also observed in other lanthanide phosphonates. It further proves the unusual thermal stability of the Ln−O−P bonds. The total weight loss in the range of 40−1000 °C is about 45.1%.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-13 were examined by thermaogravemetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C (see Figure S14-S15 in ). The TGA curve of 1 displayed two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 40 to 135 °C was observed to be about 9.1%, corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.9%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposed slowly. The second step of weight loss covered a temperature range of 327-427 °C, during which the curves showed a sharp drop, indicative of the partial combustion of the ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious exothermic peak in this temperature range, which may be illustrated as ClO4--assisted combustion of the ligands. Then the compound continued to decompose slowly above this temperature and complete decomposition was not achieved until above 1000 °C, which was also observed in other lanthanide phosphonates. It further proves the unusual thermal stability of the Ln-O-P bonds. The total weight loss in the range of 40-1000 °C is about 45.1%.

elements.content: Since compounds 4−13 show almost the same thermal decomposition process, compound 11 is selected as a representative to illustrate them in detail. The TGA curve of 11 also displayed two main steps of weight losses. In the temperature range of 40−225 °C, the weight loss was about 8.7%, corresponding to the release of all the lattice and coordinated water molecules (theoretical value 8.9%). Then the framework of the compound was stable until 375 °C, meaning that the decomposition temperature of the backbone of type II structure was about 50 °C higher than that of type I structure. A sharp weight loss was observed during the temperature range of 380−560 °C, indicating the complete combustion of the organic ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious endothermic peak in this temperature range. The final residues are a mixture of ErPO4 and Er2O3 in a ratio of 2:1. The total weight loss in the range of 40−1000 °C is about 40.9%, close to the theoretical value (43.6%).

elements.content: Eu(III)- and Tb(III)-containing complexes show strong and characteristic luminescent emissions in the visible region upon excitation of ultraviolet radiation, making them to be good candidate materials for fluoroimmunoassays and structural probes. On the other hand, Er(III)- and Yb(III)-based compounds show emissions in the near-infrared region (800−1600 nm), and the advantage of signal transmittance of near-infrared radiation makes them useful in areas such as laser systems and optical amplifiers. Bearing this in mind, we measured the solid-state luminescent spectra of the Eu (2 and 7), Tb (3 and 8), Er (11), and Yb (12) compounds at room temperature. The Er and Yb compounds showed no detectable luminescence emissions probably due to the quenching effect of the N−H groups in Hpmp ligands and O−H groups of water molecules. Compounds 2 and 7 displayed intense red luminescence emissions, while compounds 3 and 8 showed strong green luminescence emissions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

Eu(III)- and Tb(III)-containing complexes show strong and characteristic luminescent emissions in the visible region upon excitation of ultraviolet radiation, making them to be good candidate materials for fluoroimmunoassays and structural probes. On the other hand, Er(III)- and Yb(III)-based compounds show emissions in the near-infrared region (800-1600 nm), and the advantage of signal transmittance of near-infrared radiation makes them useful in areas such as laser systems and optical amplifiers. Bearing this in mind, we measured the solid-state luminescent spectra of the Eu (2 and 7), Tb (3 and 8), Er (11), and Yb (12) compounds at room temperature. The Er and Yb compounds showed no detectable luminescence emissions probably due to the quenching effect of the N-H groups in Hpmp ligands and O-H groups of water molecules. Compounds 2 and 7 displayed intense red luminescence emissions, while compounds 3 and 8 showed strong green luminescence emissions.

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure , both compounds 2 and 7 show very strong and characteristic emission spectra of Eu(III) ions upon excitation at 394 nm. Using compound 7 as an example (Figure a), the emission bands occurring at 580(w), 593(m), 616(vs), 653(w), 697(m) nm can be assigned to 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions. It is well-known that the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of Eu (III) ion is electric-dipole (ED) and extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of the Eu(III) ion. It is documented that the emission intensity increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) ion decreases, suggesting the strong symmetry dependence of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition. In contrast, the 5D0 → 7F1 transition whose emission intensity is mainly dependent on the crystal field around the Eu(III) ion is magnetic-dipole (MD) and insensitive to site symmetry. As shown in the emission spectrum, the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is about 6 times stronger than that of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, indicating the absence of an inversion center at the Eu(III) sites, in accord with the result of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is widely used as a measure of the coordination state and site symmetry of Eu(III) ions. In addition, the 5D0 → 7F0 transition induced by crystal-field J mixing is also observed in the spectrum. According to the ED selection rule, it is only allowed for the following 10 site symmetries: C s , C 1, C 2, C 3, C 4, C 6, C 2v , C 3v , C 4v , and C 6v . On the basis of the crystal structure analysis, 7 belongs to the triclinic crystal system and both of the Eu(III) ions are located on general positions, so the actual site symmetry of Eu(III) ions should be the lowest symmetry of C 1. Compound 2 belongs to the same space group as 7, and all the three crystallographically unique Eu(III) ions lie in general positions. So it is not unreasonable to anticipate that compound 2 will have a very similar emission spectrum. As shown in Figure b, the emission bands at 580(w), 592(m), 616(vs), 654(w), 699(m) nm can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions, respectively. The room temperature lifetimes of the excited 5D0 states of the Eu(III) ions were measured to be 0.29 ms (for 7) and 0.35 ms (for 2) by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions. The lifetime of 2 is slightly longer than that of 7, very consistent with the fact that there are one more emission centers in type I structure than in type II structure, just as revealed by single crystal structure analysis.
elements.clean_text: As illustrated in Figure , both compounds 2 and 7 show very strong and characteristic emission spectra of Eu(III) ions upon excitation at 394 nm. Using compound 7 as an example (Figure a), the emission bands occurring at 580(w), 593(m), 616(vs), 653(w), 697(m) nm can be assigned to 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions. It is well-known that the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of Eu (III) ion is electric-dipole (ED) and extremely sensitive to chemical bonds in the vicinity of the Eu(III) ion. It is documented that the emission intensity increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) ion decreases, suggesting the strong symmetry dependence of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition. In contrast, the 5D0 → 7F1 transition whose emission intensity is mainly dependent on the crystal field around the Eu(III) ion is magnetic-dipole (MD) and insensitive to site symmetry. As shown in the emission spectrum, the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is about 6 times stronger than that of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, indicating the absence of an inversion center at the Eu(III) sites, in accord with the result of the single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The intensity ratio of I(5D0 → 7F2)/I(5D0 → 7F1) is widely used as a measure of the coordination state and site symmetry of Eu(III) ions. In addition, the 5D0 → 7F0 transition induced by crystal-field J mixing is also observed in the spectrum. According to the ED selection rule, it is only allowed for the following 10 site symmetries: C  s , C 1, C 2, C 3, C 4, C 6, C 2v , C 3v , C 4v , and C 6v . On the basis of the crystal structure analysis, 7 belongs to the triclinic crystal system and both of the Eu(III) ions are located on general positions, so the actual site symmetry of Eu(III) ions should be the lowest symmetry of C 1. Compound 2 belongs to the same space group as 7, and all the three crystallographically unique Eu(III) ions lie in general positions. So it is not unreasonable to anticipate that compound 2 will have a very similar emission spectrum. As shown in Figure b, the emission bands at 580(w), 592(m), 616(vs), 654(w), 699(m) nm can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions, respectively. The room temperature lifetimes of the excited 5D0 states of the Eu(III) ions were measured to be 0.29 ms (for 7) and 0.35 ms (for 2) by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions. The lifetime of 2 is slightly longer than that of 7, very consistent with the fact that there are one more emission centers in type I structure than in type II structure, just as revealed by single crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: Similarly, compounds 3 and 8 show comparable emission spectra (Figure ). So compound 8 is selected as a representative. Upon the excitation at 319 nm, compound 8 gave typical Tb(III) emissions in the range of 460−640 nm, and these emissions are attributed to the transition from the excited 5D4 state to the different J-levels of the lower 7FJ state: 5D4 → 7F6 at 489 nm, 5D4 → 7F5 at 546 nm, 5D4 → 7F4 at 584 nm, and 5D4 → 7F3 at 621 nm (Figure b). The spectrum is dominated by the 5D4 → 7F5 transition, which gave a strong green luminescent output for the sample. The room temperature lifetimes of the excited 5D4 states of the Tb(III) ions were measured to be 1.03 ms (for 8) and 1.35 ms (for 3) by monitoring the 5D4 → 7F5 transitions.

elements.content: Making a comparison of emission spectra between the two structural types, we will found that type I and type II structure compounds have very similar luminescence properties, except that the luminescence lifetimes of type I structure are slightly longer than those in type II structure. All of the four compounds have long luminescence lifetimes at the millisecond order, comparable to some other similar Eu(III) and Tb(III) containing complexes. On the basis of investigations on the luminescence properties of the two types of Eu and Tb compounds, we can anticipate that they may be good candidates as efficient red and green light-emitting luminescent materials, respectively.

elements.content: In conclusion, 13 rare earth metal oxalatophosphonates with three closely related structural types (I, II, and III) have been synthesized by the synergistic coordination of N-piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid and oxalic acid with trivalent rare earth metal ions under hydrothermal conditions. The type I structure represents the first example of 2D lanthanide oxalatophosphonates, while type II and type III structures feature two kinds of 3D frameworks, and the later is a symbiotic product of the former. The influence of reaction conditions such as pH value, reaction temperature, counterion, and stoichiometry of the starting materials on the structures was investigated in detail. The results show that high pH, low temperature, large counterion (ClO4 −), and low C2O4 2− ratio favor the formation of type I structure. Additionally, thermogravimetric analyses show that type II structure is more stable than type I structure. So we can conclude that type I structure is a kinetics-controlled product, and type II structure is a thermodynamics-controlled one, while type III structure is a product controlled by both thermodynamics and kinetics. Solid-state photoluminescence property measurements were performed on the two types of Eu and Tb compounds. Although there are some differences between type I and type II structures, they belong to the same space group (P1̅), and all the luminescence emission centers in them have the same C 1 symmetry. It is not strange that they displayed very similar luminescence emission spectra even though the luminescence lifetimes of the type I structure were slightly longer than those in type II structure. This is also not contradictory to the fact that property is always dependent on structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, 13 rare earth metal oxalatophosphonates with three closely related structural types (I, II, and III) have been synthesized by the synergistic coordination of N-piperidinomethane-1-phosphonic acid and oxalic acid with trivalent rare earth metal ions under hydrothermal conditions. The type I structure represents the first example of 2D lanthanide oxalatophosphonates, while type II and type III structures feature two kinds of 3D frameworks, and the later is a symbiotic product of the former. The influence of reaction conditions such as pH value, reaction temperature, counterion, and stoichiometry of the starting materials on the structures was investigated in detail. The results show that high pH, low temperature, large counterion (ClO4 -), and low C2O4 2- ratio favor the formation of type I structure. Additionally, thermogravimetric analyses show that type II structure is more stable than type I structure. So we can conclude that type I structure is a kinetics-controlled product, and type II structure is a thermodynamics-controlled one, while type III structure is a product controlled by both thermodynamics and kinetics. Solid-state photoluminescence property measurements were performed on the two types of Eu and Tb compounds. Although there are some differences between type I and type II structures, they belong to the same space group (P1̅), and all the luminescence emission centers in them have the same C 1 symmetry. It is not strange that they displayed very similar luminescence emission spectra even though the luminescence lifetimes of the type I structure were slightly longer than those in type II structure. This is also not contradictory to the fact that property is always dependent on structure.

A mixture of Gd(ClO4)3 (1 M, 0.5 mL, 0.5 mmol) and H2pmp·HCl (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol) dissolved in deionized water (4 mL) was stirred and heated to about 90 °C on a heating plate. The pH value was adjusted to 5.1 by adding 0.5 M aqueous NaOH dropwise. Then 2 mL of aqueous Na2C2O4 (0.010 g, 0.075 mmol) was added. The clear solution thus formed was maintained undisturbed at 100 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 1 °C/h. Colorless rod-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with deionized water, and air-dried. Yield: 88% (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C22H67Cl2Gd3N3O39P3 (1633.35): C, 16.18; H, 4.13; N, 2.57%. Found: C, 16.23; H, 4.03; N, 2.48%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3408(vs, br), 2950(m), 2788(w), 1648(vs), 1457(w), 1317(m), 1114(vs), 1010(s), 797(w), 627(m), 564(w), 500(w).

Synthesis of [Ln<sub>3</sub>(Hpmp)<sub>3</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·9H<sub>2</sub>O [Ln = Eu (<bold>2</bold>), Tb (<bold>3</bold>)]

A mixture of Ln(ClO4)3 (1 M, 1 mL, 1 mmol) and H2pmp·HCl (0.216 g, 1 mmol) dissolved in deionized water (7 mL) was stirred and heated to about 90 °C on a heating plate. The pH value was adjusted to 5.1 by adding 0.5 M aqueous NaOH dropwise. Then 4 mL of aqueous Na2C2O4 (0.041 g, 0.3 mmol) was added slowly with vigorous stirring. White precipitates appeared immediately. The mixture thus formed was stirred for 30 more minutes and then cooled to room temperature. The white precipitates were collected by vacuum filtration, washed repeatedly with deionized water, ethanol, and vacuum-dried overnight. Yield: 75% for 2 (based on Na2C2O4). Calcd for C22H67Cl2Eu3N3O39P3 (1617.48): C, 16.34; H, 4.18; N, 2.60%. Found: C, 16.27; H, 4.04; N, 2.42%. Synthesis of [Gd<sub>3</sub>(Hpmp)(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>) and [Gd<sub>2</sub>(Hpmp)(C<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

A mixture of GdCl3·6H2O (0.156 g, 0.42 mmol), H2pmp·HCl (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), Na2C2O4(0.054 g, 0.4 mmol), and deionized water (8 mL) was stirred, while 0.5 M aqueous NaOH was added drop by drop until the pH value reached 3.8. After 0.5 h of stirring, it was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, and heated at 135 °C for 96 h, then slowly cooled down to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C/h. Colorless block-shaped crystals of compounds 4 and 5 were recovered by filtration, washed repeatedly with deionized water, and air-dried. Overall yield: 49% (based on Na2C2O4, calculated as the average yield of compounds 4 and 5). Calcd for C14H35Gd3NO30P (4) (1200.14): C, 14.01; H, 2.94; N, 1.17%; C11H21Gd2NO17P (5) (784.76): C, 16.84; H, 2.70; N, 1.78%. Found: C, 15.66; H, 2.72; N, 1.50%. cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−13 were examined by thermaogravemetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C (see Figure S14−S15 in ). The TGA curve of 1 displayed two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 40 to 135 °C was observed to be about 9.1%, corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.9%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposed slowly. The second step of weight loss covered a temperature range of 327−427 °C, during which the curves showed a sharp drop, indicative of the partial combustion of the ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious exothermic peak in this temperature range, which may be illustrated as ClO4−-assisted combustion of the ligands. Then the compound continued to decompose slowly above this temperature and complete decomposition was not achieved until above 1000 °C, which was also observed in other lanthanide phosphonates. It further proves the unusual thermal stability of the Ln−O−P bonds. The total weight loss in the range of 40−1000 °C is about 45.1%.

Since compounds 4−13 show almost the same thermal decomposition process, compound 11 is selected as a representative to illustrate them in detail. The TGA curve of 11 also displayed two main steps of weight losses. In the temperature range of 40−225 °C, the weight loss was about 8.7%, corresponding to the release of all the lattice and coordinated water molecules (theoretical value 8.9%). Then the framework of the compound was stable until 375 °C, meaning that the decomposition temperature of the backbone of type II structure was about 50 °C higher than that of type I structure. A sharp weight loss was observed during the temperature range of 380−560 °C, indicating the complete combustion of the organic ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious endothermic peak in this temperature range. The final residues are a mixture of ErPO4 and Er2O3 in a ratio of 2:1. The total weight loss in the range of 40−1000 °C is about 40.9%, close to the theoretical value (43.6%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-13 were examined by thermaogravemetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere from 40 to 1000 °C (see Figure S14-S15 in ). The TGA curve of 1 displayed two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 40 to 135 °C was observed to be about 9.1%, corresponding to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.9%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposed slowly. The second step of weight loss covered a temperature range of 327-427 °C, during which the curves showed a sharp drop, indicative of the partial combustion of the ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious exothermic peak in this temperature range, which may be illustrated as ClO4--assisted combustion of the ligands. Then the compound continued to decompose slowly above this temperature and complete decomposition was not achieved until above 1000 °C, which was also observed in other lanthanide phosphonates. It further proves the unusual thermal stability of the Ln-O-P bonds. The total weight loss in the range of 40-1000 °C is about 45.1%.

Since compounds 4-13 show almost the same thermal decomposition process, compound 11 is selected as a representative to illustrate them in detail. The TGA curve of 11 also displayed two main steps of weight losses. In the temperature range of 40-225 °C, the weight loss was about 8.7%, corresponding to the release of all the lattice and coordinated water molecules (theoretical value 8.9%). Then the framework of the compound was stable until 375 °C, meaning that the decomposition temperature of the backbone of type II structure was about 50 °C higher than that of type I structure. A sharp weight loss was observed during the temperature range of 380-560 °C, indicating the complete combustion of the organic ligands. As exhibited in the corresponding DTA curve (), there was an obvious endothermic peak in this temperature range. The final residues are a mixture of ErPO4 and Er2O3 in a ratio of 2:1. The total weight loss in the range of 40-1000 °C is about 40.9%, close to the theoretical value (43.6%).

decomposition temperature.type: release of all the lattice and coordinated water molecules
complete combustion of the organic ligands
